div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,585] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, AUGUST 30, 1906 [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through steamers for Marseilles ad London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train deluxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £ 1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 13-9-906

div.head: "IS THE CAUCASIAN PLAYED OUT?"
div.p: We may fairly take it for granted that when Mr. Bret Harte's hero "Truthful James" propounded the inquiry which forms the heading of this article he did not use the term Caucasian in any subtle or narrow ethnological sense, but simply as connoting the white man in contradistinction to his yellow, black, or other coloured red brethren. The question still stands, and contemporary events are contributing to invest it with a considerable degree of interest and even of importance. The supremacy of the Indo European races in arms, policy, and civilisation has lasted so long and appears to be so firmly founded that we are in some danger of forgetting that it is comparatively modern. The era of European supremacy Commenced at Marathon and Salamis; it culminated with the expulsion of the Moors from Spain, and it was completed by Sobieski at Vienna. Since then the white nations have, directly or indirectly, ruled the world, and the others have, more or less willingly, accepted the assumption, and occasionally the assertion, of their own inferiority. Recent indications, however, says the "Morning Post," are not wanting to show that an alteration is beginning to take place in the situation, and that the long standing hegemony of the Caucasian is in process of being challenged.

This movement—if such it may be termed— has, of course, received an enormous stimulus from the example of Japan, which has emerged from the seclusion of Orientalism and successfully made its claim to a position among the Great Powers. The defeat of Russia has naturally produced a powerful effect in China, and it is not difficult to trace a direct connection between this cause and the practical supersession of Sir Robert Hart, who stood as the very embodiment of European influence in the Celestial Kingdom. That a certain amount of discontent exists in India is admitted by all who are familiar with that country. It is largely inarticulate, but it is nevertheless real, and not even the acknowledged justice of the English role has prevented the growth of a certain vague sentiment of nationality. The agitation in Persia is mainly domestic in its character and has probably been allayed by the recent concession of Parliamentary institutions but it is significant to read that "it is feared that the representatives of the people will demand the dismissal of the Belgian Customs employés and of the Belgian Minister of Customs and Posts." It is believed that a similar state of feeling prevails with regard to the Danish officials in Siam, though the subjects of King Chulalongkorn have not as yet made any active protest. In Egypt again there is to be noticed a spirit of restiveness—not entirely factitious. In South Africa, where the black man stands upon an infinitely lower plane of civilisation than is found in the coutries above referred to, the spread of Ethiopianism already constitutes a serious menace, and may be found to supply the instrument hitherto lacking of cohesion and unification for the native tribes. The Pan-Islamic propaganda is doubtless essentially and fundamentally a question of religion, but it is surely something more than an accident that it should be actually bounded within such strict limitations of race and colour as to be for all practical purposes anti Caucasian in its operation. The aggregate of cases cited above constitutes a somewhat remarkable illustration of the extent to which the steady, if almost subconscious, revolt against the hitherto unquestioned domination of the white races has spread itself. It by no means proves that the Caucasian is "played out," but it may afford the student of social seismography ground for conjecturing that the ethnic centre of gravity of the world is perhaps less stable than it was supposed to be.

div.head: SYMPATHY WITH THE SULTAN.
div.p: Unbiassed reports received at Constantinople from various important centres in the interior of both European and Asiatic Turkey show that there were remarkable demonstrations of sympathy when the news of the Sultan's indisposition was received.

The Moslems gathered in the mosques and offered up prayers for the speedy recovery of his Majesty, and the announcement of his restoration to health caused much rejoicing among the people, a fact which is regarded as a striking testimony to his popularity.

Information during the course of his Majesty's illness has been of the most meagre kind. The Sultan, when indisposed, becomes a hermit of the most rigorous type. He shuts himself up in the harem—that is to say, the part of the Palace reserved for the Royal family and only the chief of women attendants may approach and communicate with him.

It is probable that on this occasion the physicians were admitted to the Royal presence, but as a rule the Sultan gets his medical advice from some servant who has informed a physician of his master's symptoms.

Even in the present illness one American doctor was consulted by a chamberlain at his own house, and the advice was conveyed to the Sultan. The Royal disease—hematuria— is not dangerous under constant medical care, but the Sultan's hatred of physicians gives a graver side to his case.

div.head: Dredging at Suez.
div.p: The total credit of L. E. 3,000 for dredging the Suez roads has been expended.

div.head: French Garden.
div.p: At the French Garden this evening, a gala performance will be given in aid of the Home for the Aged.

div.head: Coal Contract.
div.p: Messrs. Morgan Wakley & Co., Ltd., have secured the Khedivial Mail Line tender for 30,000 tons of Welsh coal for Alexandria.

div.head: Business Announcement.
div.p: Messrs. Stamatopoulo Bros, have transferred their offices to Cherif Pasha street, near the Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris, exproperty Amiroli.

div.head: The Suez-Nakhl Wire.
div.p: Of the total credit of L.E. 3,100 for the new line of telegraph from Suez to Nakhl, on the Sinaitic frontier. L.E. 1,609 has already been spent on the work.

div.head: Agricultural Pests.
div.p: The draft law authorizing the application of the articles of Laws III. and XIII. applies not only to cotton worm but to all other parasites that prey on agriculture.

div.head: Locomotive on Fire.
div.p: The locomotive of the 6.20 Matarieh train caught fire on its arrival at Koubbeh-les-Bains yesterday afternoon. Another engine took on the train while the fire was being extinguished.

div.head: Fatal Accident.
div.p: While an old woman was walking in Moussastreet, Damanhour, on Thursday last, a water cart ran into her, causing injuries to her breast, to which she succumbed on Tuesday.

div.head: Post Office Forgery.
div.p: Hashim Bey Abdel-Fattah, proprietor of "Al Ummeh," is considered by the Parquet as having been an accomplice of Ibrahim Ragi in the Post Office forgery case. He has been allowed out on bail for LE 100.

div.head: Drowning Accidents.
div.p: A native boy was drowned on Tuesday in a canal near Shoubra, and another native was drowned on the same day in the Nile near Tourah. The two bodies were taken out and allowed to be buried after post-mortem examination.

div.head: Accession Day.
div.p: On Saturday evening at 8 o'clock, H. E. the Regent will give an official dinner at Ras-El- Tin in honour of the Sultan's Accession Day. This will be followed by a display of fireworks in front of the Palace. H.E. Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha being absent on Europe, the usual reception will not take place at No. 3 Palace.

div.head: Cairo Motor Accident.
div.p: The Parquet has concluded its inquiry into the circumstances attending the motor car accident in which the lady companion of Yessin Bey Mustapha recently met her death. As a result, the chauffeur of the automobile and the driver of the cart with which it collided are to be brought before the Esbekieh Native Court for trial on Tuesday next. Yessin Bey Mustapha will attend the trial as witness.

div.head: The Sersina Affair.
div.p: After leaving Alexandria, Mr. Kershaw, the new chef de parquet, wet to Shibin el Korm, whence he proceeded on Tuesday morning to Sersina village, accompanied by Moberly Bey, Inspector to the Ministry of the Interior, and the chef de parquet of Shibin. The officials took up quarters at the Sersina police outpost, to which they summoned the omdeh of that village and the native witnesses.

div.head: Bribery and Corruption.
div.p: Numerous charges which are now preferred against the four native secret police who are accused of irregularity form quite a revelation of bribery and corruption in the secret service. According to a contemporary, the gang were under the leadership of Mohamed Naghar, and between them they extorted no little bashish from the opium-den holders as the price of official hoodwink. The plot was discovered by a lieutenant of the same service, and the matter being reported to headquarters they got notice to quit Alexandria in twenty-four hours. The four were all natives of Port Said, and were all of them landed proprietors.

div.head: The Month of September.
div.p: September marks the last month of the holidays. Those who wish to still profit by their leisure and by good advice, will not fail to sign for a course of lessons in English, French, Arabic, Italian, German, etc., at the Berlitz School in Cairo, No. 1, rue Kamel ; in Alexandria, 12, rue Rosette. Classes for pupils of all ages. Lessons at the school and at private residences. [Advt.].

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: BREAKING THE RECORD.
THE NEW KHEDIVIAL LINER.
div.p: The S.S. Osmanieh, which left Southampton on Wednesday afternoon, 22nd inst., arrived at Malta on Tuesday morning, and after coaling left the same evening for Alexandria, where she is expected to arrive this evening.

The voyage from England will thus have occupied only 8 days, including the stop of 12 hours at Malta, so that the steaming time to Alexandria, viz., 7 ½ days, constitutes an easy record for the long-sea route.
We are informed that the vessel will be thrown open for the inspection of the public on certain days next week, which will be duly announced in the press later.

div.head: THE ANGLO EGYPTIAN MAILS.
div.p: A correspondent calls attention in the "Tribuna" (Rome) to the risks attending the transhipment of the Anglo-Egyptian and Anglo- Indian mails at Brindisi, where, it appears, the postbags are thrown from the boat on to the ground in the midst of dust-heaps in summer and mud in winter. At the same time the narrow road is continually being used by carts and foot passengers, to the confusion of the officials whose duty it is to count the bags before patting them into the vans. The correspondent points out the necessity of at least paving this road, failing which be suggests the building of a proper shed for the protection of the mails from sun and rain. "After all," he concludes, "the service is an international one, and its safety should be properly guaranteed. It is to be hoped that the Government will take steps to avoid possible accidents, and Italy's consequent responsibility towards the countries concerned."

div.head: EGYPTIAN AGRICULTURAL MISSION AT MILAN EXHIBITION.
div.p: The Egyptian official Agricultural Mission was received by the Vice-President and the Commit- tee of the Milan Exhibition on the 21st inst. Visits were paid to the agrarian section of the exhibition and the agricultural institutes of the city. The mission has opened negotiations with manufacturers of agricultural machinery in order to obtain their support for the Agrarian Exhibition to be held at Cairo in November.

div.head: LATE PRINCE MOHAMED IBRAHIM.
div.p: The body of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, who was killed in the automobile accident at Thiberville, was yesterday week brought to Paris. The body was placed in a lead coffin in presence of the members of the family with the accustomed ceremonial of the Mussulman religion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to the under mentioned officers of the Egyptian Army :– El Miralai Herbert Bey, Assistant Adjutant General, Recruiting Department, until October 16 ; El Kaimakam Brakenridge Bey, Medical Corps, until October 31 ; El Bimbashi Moore, Staff officer of the Hired Transport, until November 4 ; El Bimbashi Hughes, Medical Corps, until October ; El Bimbashi Stuart-Wortley, 11th Sudanese, until November 4.

One month's extension of leave has been granted to El Miralai Griffiths Bey, D.S.O.. principal veterinary surgeon, and El Miralai Dickinson Bey, Governor of the Blue Nile province, who will resume their duties accordingly on October 7 and 10 respectively. One month's sick leave has been granted to El Bimbashi Lucas, 11th Sudanese.
El Bimbashi G. Hilhouse, Sudan Government, has completed his term of service with the Egyptian Army, and is accordingly struck off the strength thereof.
Lieutenant R.C. Greenwood, Highland Light Infantry, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi and is ported to the 3rd Battalion.

div.head: A SANITARY NUISANCE.
div.p: A correspondent writes from Cairo to complain of the unwholesome odours which emanate from the Savoy extensions now under construction, on account of the insanitary and disgusting habits of the numerous native workmen employed, and asks as to draw the attention of the sanitary authorities to this objectionable state of affairs. The Kasr el Nil district is one of the most fashionable quarters of Cairo, and it is to be hoped that our correspondent's complaint will meet with attention. Might we suggest that when more than a certain number of workmen, say ten or fifteen, are employed on buildings the contractors should be compelled to erect temporary lieux d'aisance and be responsible for their maintenance in a proper condition.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: As already announced, there will be a children's ball to-morrow afternoon, besides a concert by the Bracale orchestra. On Saturday afternoon there will be another concert, and also on Sunday morning, of which the following is the programme :—
Marche—Prophete—Meyerheen
Valse—Fruhlingsstimmen—Straus
Ouverture—Saul—Bazzini
Fantaisie—Tannhauser—Wagner
Scenes Hongroises—Massenet

div.head: LORD CROMER CRITICISED.
MR. WILFRED BLUNT'S BOOK.
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, as if smarting vicariously under the lash lately inflicted upon Arabs at Denishwai, has retorted with an indictment of Lord Cromer's administration of law as between natives and the army of occupation. Under the title of "Atrocities of Justice under British Rule in Egypt," it will be issued in a fortnight by Mr. Fisher Unwin.

div.head: LITTLE ENGLANDERS ON LORD CROMER.
div.p: Mr. Stead, writing in the latest "Review of Reviews" on "The Scare in Egypt," says :— Lord Cromer has been in Egypt so long that he has come to be regarded as a permanent institution. Perhaps he has been there too long. It would have been treason to suggest such a thing three months ago But to day I am not so sure Lord Cromer first of all reduced the English garrison, and then getting "rattled," as the Americans say, he suddenly insists upon its reinforcement. That might he excused, but a much more serious matter is the alarm which he caused Sir Edward Grey to sound in the House of Commons as to the parlous condition of things in Egypt. Of course he may be right now. In that case he was wrong last year, for it can hardly be contended that the situation has changed so suddenly for the worse. The Sultan has been headed off in the East, and there has been no serious eruption in the West. The fact is that it is about time Lord Cromer were to be asked when he intends setting about the establishment of some kind of representative institution in Egypt. It is no use our pretending to be so mightily zealous for the success of the Duma in Russia, when we do nothing to fulfil our solemn pledges to set up a Duma in Egypt. It is certainly a much more easy task to manage fellaheen through representative institutions than it is to manage the Russian revolutionists.

The "Daily News," in a recent issue, voices a far more favourable opinion and says: Anyone who knows Lord Cromer will realise the immense debt that Egypt owes to his manifold labours in her behalf. His personal affability to all under his sway reminds us of the state of our rule in India when a man crossed from the Punjaub to Calcutta, and thence to the Hills, in order to see John Lawrence about a cow. We fear that that good day has passed from India for the time being. We rejoice that it prevails in Egypt.

div.head: MR FINDLAY AND THE PRESS.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of a London paper, discussing the charges of bribery brought by j Mr. Findlay against the Press in his telegram . to Sir E. Grey, says: — The telegram containing the charges most be considered a privileged one, and although, as none of us doubt, Mr. Findlay has overwhelming proofs at hand, such proofs most remain locked up in the secret dossier, for their publication would doubtless J implicate some foreign political persons of high standing.

div.head: EGYPTIAN "PATRIOTISM."
div.p: Under date of the 26th inst. "Al Minbar" writes :—To whatever extent the wise ones among the Egyptians may differ from the Editor of "Al Lewa" with regard to his policy on questions of patriotism, all are undoubtedly agreed that he has rendered a great service to his country by going to London this summer and meeting certain well-known writers and orators. If his success were confined to the fact that he made Mr. Robertson oppose Sir E. Grey and force him to modify his statements regarding fanaticism, it would have sufficed. No wonder that the English in Egypt, who do not wish the Egyptian's voice to be heard in England, should feel vexed and should try to lower him in the estimation of the English public and to get the French Press to accuse him of serving Turkey and Germany. We have already said that the charge made against him of taking money from the rich notables of Egypt is an honour for it shows the existence of a party in Egypt that upholds his policy. The English do not wish to see the like of him in this country, but this feeling will not make them try to get rid of him for fear of the power of the British public who allow no one to interfere with the liberty of the Press. The journey of the Editor of "Al Lewa" to England this summer will not facilitate the work of his exile and we do not think the Anglo-Egyptians will add to their mistakes after the Denishwai affair by taking any such measure. It is time that we should do away with professional jealousy and personal differences. Patriotism requires that we should do so.

div.head: SULTAN'S ENVOY IN CHAINS
div.p: The Emir Abdullah Sadik. a former chief of the Abyssinian Mission in Constantinople, has been arrested on a charge of high treason by the authorities at Zeila, British Somaliland, and has been handed in chains to the Abyssinian authorities.

The Emir was sent by the Sultan to preach a holy war among the Mohamedan tribes of East Africa, and is said also to have been entrusted with a mission for the attempted conversion of the Mikado to Islam. Compromising papers were found in his possession.
The Emir is also charged with having stolen £10,000 worth of jewellery from a Singapore merchant.

div.head: RESPECTING ANTHEMS.
UNSEEMLY CONDUCT IN ESBEKIEH.
div.p: "A Twenty Years' Resident in Egypt" (Cairo) writes : —Having attended the military concert given in the Esbekieh public garden of Cairo on the last two occasions, I wish to bring to the notice of those whom it may concern, that when the Khedivial Anthem was being played by the British military band at the dose of the concert, almost every one of the civilian Englishmen present remained seated, instead of standing up and removing their hats, as used to be customary. Other foreigners present, probably influenced by the action of the Englishmen, treat his Highness the Khedive in the same manner, and in some cases suggest that as most of the Englishmen are highly-paid officials, drawing pay from the Government of his Highness, it may be that by thus showing their want of respect they are carrying out the wishes of some one in high official authority.

So far as Englishmen are concerned, the difference can immediately be seen when the band plays "God save the King" at the finish of the programme, but the foreigners present show exactly the same want of respect to "God save the King" as the Englishmen do to the Khedivial anthem, and some of them have been heard to remark, "If Englishmen who draw pay from the Khedive will not respect the Khedivial anthem, why should we take, any notice of that of their King?"

Some of the Egyptians present consider this an action of the British authorities, with a view to the creation, if possible, of a disturbance and more trouble, and as a means of "killing" respect for the Khedive.

It is only fair to mention that on the last occasion, a highly placed British Army staff officer being present, every Englishman in army uniform, whether serving with the British or Egyptian forces, sprang to "attention" and came smartly to the salute, as if on a ceremonial parade, and remained "at the salute" during the whole of the playing of both anthems, thus paying exactly the same respect to the Khedivial anthem as to "God save the King."

How very nice it would look, how pleasant it would make things here, and how much it would be appreciated, if all civilians would be forced to either do likewise, or keep out of the gardens and other places while the army bands are playing.

Some years ago a similar state of affairs (with regard to civilians and the British national anthem) was brought to notice at Gibraltar, when the Governor and Commander-in-chief of the "Rock" placed a sentry on each gate of the public gardens while the military bands were playing there, with orders "to permit only members of the Army and Navy to enter the garden," and in addition military bands were prevented from playing at private parties until further orders. This soon had the desired effect, as civilians, when re-admitted (after presenting a petition) showed no farther want of respeot for the National Anthem.

If it would only be made known by the authorities, that if civilians continue their present want of respect for both anthems the action of the Gibraltar authorities would be copied and enforced in Cairo, a marked improvement would soon be noticed.

Government officials and others might be informed that if they were ashamed to show respect to the anthem of the head of the Government by which they are employed, they should equally be ashamed to draw their pay from that source, and could take service in another country where their feelings would not suffer by showing the respect due to the Head of the State by which they were employed.
To allay their susceptibilities they might be informed that by saluting the Khedive's anthem they are not paying respect to a personality, but to the recognised Head of a State.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS THEATRE.
div.p: M. Louis Gardet, the impresario, whose company is holding the boards of the Alhambra, has arrived in Cairo to arrange for the début of his company at the Esbekieh Gardens Theatre on September 5 with the amusing vaudeville Le Billet de Logement. The repertoire of the troupe is excellent, containing more than thirty pieces which have met with great success at Alexandria, including L'Arlesienna, Zola's L'Assommoir, Les Dragées d' Hercule, Une Affaire Scandaleuse, Une Nuit des Noces, etc., etc. The names of some of the artistes are well-known in Cairo, as for instance those of Mesdames Jane Marney and Valentine Darmy, who are sure to be warmly welcomed, and we might also mention MM. Lacroix, Smits, Laugé, Dornay, and Mmes. Laurentine and Bellanger.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: The Band 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers (by kind permission of Lieutenant Colonel J.H. Gideon and officers) will play the following programme in the Esbekieh Gardens to-morrow (Friday), commencing at 9 p.m.

2. Scéne Espagnol—Sevillana— Elgar.

div.head: "VOLCANO" NEAR CAIRO.
AN EXTRAORDINARY RUMOR.
div.p: Egypt has never, within the historical period at any rate, been remarkable for any volcanic phenomenon. The country also is very slightly amenable to earthquakes, although to the north, in the Archipelago, earthquakes are frequent. The happy immunity of this country from volcanoes and their concomitants has engendered the idea that despite the terrible eruptions and earthquakes in Martinique, San Francisco, Naples and Chili, the Valley of the Nile will remain unbothered by such nuisances. However, a "bolt from the blue" has fallen at Cairo, and it has been confidently affirmed that a volcano has made its appearance on the Mokattam Hills. The "Progrès" in its issue of yesterday states:—

Des rumeurs publiques sont mises en circulation d'après lesquelles en petit volcan aurait ètè dècouvert sur la montagne adjacente à Helouan et à une heure de distance de l'observatoire de cette localité. M. Forti, da service de l'observatoire, est chargé de chargé de contrôler la nouvelle d'après laquelle le volcan formerait de petits cratères.

Other Cairo newspapers also give publicity to the same information and considerable perturbation has been caused by this most sensational intelligence. It appears, however, that the volcano is discovered to be an ancient tomb, and the Cairo newspapers have evidently been led astray by some practical joker.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers met this morning at San Stefano and approved the following An arrêté to quality sols of police as officials of courts.
An arrêté to modify Article VI. of the Khedivial Edict issued on the 13th July, 1891, in regard to vagabonds.

An arrêté prescribing the necessary measures for the protection of cotton plantations. A credit of L.E 2,377, for the Ministry of the Interior, for the erection of a building for the Sharkin Markaz and its Summary Court, including the price of the ground.
A credit of L.E. 660 for the Ministry of Public Works, for the enlargement of the Mortgage Department in the Cairo Mixed Court.
A credit of L.E 1,875 for creating a post office at Aïyat.
A credit of L.E. 2,400 for erecting special cells in the Criminal Court prison, to be used for separating men from women, and prisoners of evil antecedents from first offenders.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS TRAMWAYS.
div.p: The following is the plan, sanctioned by the Public Works Department, of the electric tramway which the Cairo Electric Railway and Heliopolis Co. propose to lay down between Cairo and Heliopolis : Traversing the principal boulevards of the second and first cases, the line will cross the desert straight to the present terminus of the Cairo tramways at Abbassieh, whence to Bab el Hadid, the city permanent way will be used ; after which station the route will be viâ the metropolitan line, Ismailia Canal, Djellal Pasha-street to Boulac avenue. Hence, once more the line will follow the city tramway and make the loop round the buildings of the Mixed Courts, for the return to the Oasis.

div.head: RAILWAY EXTENSION IN SYRIA.
div.p: The extension of the railway line from Hamah to Aleppo has been completed, and direct communication is established with Beyrout. The line joins the Damascus Beyrout Railway at Rayak. The distance between Rayak and Aleppo is 332 kilomètres. The inauguration will take place in September, and the line will be opened to traffic towards the end of October.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon, and is due here on Sunday morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Seti arrived at Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, and is due here about the 12th prox., with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Messageries steamer Niger arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday morning.

div.head: REMARKABLE OPERATION.
div.p: A working hoy, aged twelve, by accident put his leg into a tank full of boiling liquid in an establishment where he was employed in Milan. He was carried to the hospital, and the physicians declared it impossible to save the leg unless by surrounding it with living flesh, upon which A. Pozzi, a strong, brave young man, presented himself at the hospital offering his own flesh. Two pieces were cut from his legs and arms and applied to the boy's burnt and fleshless leg. Adhesion proved complete, and the invalid already is remarkably better.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl of Lovelace, whose death is announced in to-day's telegrams, was the son of Lord Byron's only daughter. The heir to the Earldom is his half brother, the Hon. Lionel Noel, while the Barony of Wentworth, which descended to him through his mother from Lady Byron, goes to Lady Ada Milbanke. Mr. Wilfred Scawen Blunt married Lady Anne Noel, daughter of the first Earl of Lovelace.
Crookshank Pasha and family have left Vitrol for Paris and London, and do not return to Cairo till the end of October.
Dr. Nolan is expected to return to Cairo on the 4th prox. from Adalia, where he has been spending his leave.
Miralai Hopkinson Bey. Commandant of Police, Alexandria, has been granted 38 days' leave of absence.
Two months' leave of absence, on medical certificate, has been granted to Yessin Mustapha Bey, Moudir of Keneh.
Morice Bey and Mr. Kershaw are to remain in the Parquet of the Native Court of Appeal for the time being.

In memoriam of the late Mohamed Pasha Cherif, Ibrahim Bey Cherif has presented the El Orwa El Woska Benevolent Society with twenty pounds. In the sudden death from peritonitis, following on an operation, of Mrs. Kumm, better known as Miss Lucy Guinness, a daughter of the Rev. H. Grattan Guinness, D.D., founder of the Regions Beyond Missionary Union, the foreign mission field has lost an eloquent advocate both by voice and pen. Since her marriage she had, in company with her husband, Dr. Karl Kumm, of the Sudan United Mission, sought to awaken interest in that neglected and difficult quarter, and it was while touring in the United States on behalf of African evangelisation that she succumbed to her illness, at Northfield, the place so long associated with the labours of Mr. D. L Moody.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit— within certain necessary limits— free discussion.

div.head: DISORDERLY CAFES.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—While the Alexandria police are wasting all their energies on an absolutely absurd campaign for the so called purification of Alexandria, they are neglecting other matters of public decency. At the corner of Nehi Daniel-street, behind the Pharmacy Vais, the Alexandria Municipality have licensed some Berbereen coffee-houses, which are a disgrace to the neighbourhood. All round there are excellent houses, and yet, for the sake of a few napoleons the year, the Alexandria Municipality renders the quarter uninhabitable. The rent for the footway is P.T. 40 per square metre which is all the Municipality can demand, and it would not be a great financial sacrifice to suppress these cafés, which are a fearful nuisance to the neighbours. Miralai Hopkinson Bey could easily induce the Municipality, in the interests of public decency, to do away with these coffee-houses, for the Alexandria City Police have a right to enforce the attention of the Municipality "pour l'ordre public" to this eyesore on a good thoroughfare. I am, etc.
ALEXANDRIAN.

div.head: OBJECTIONABLE POSTCARDS.
div.p: To THB EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—ONE hears much of the zeal of the Morality Department of Alexandria. May I direct its attention to the filthy picture cards unblushingly offered for sale in the windows and on the side walls of shops in the rue Gare de Ramleh ? This practice is perhaps a remote cause, but nevertheless it cannot but be a cause of the corruption of the youth of towns in Egypt, and, as demand creates supply, hence the facility with which disorderly houses are 'run' in Alexandria, and hence the necessity English people here feel for sending their boy children to England for their education—Yours faithfully,
J. GOODING.
Alexandria, August 29.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICAIRE
TRIBUNAL SOMMAIRE MIXTE D'ALEXANDRIE
UN CONFLIT ENTRE NEGOCIANT ET COMPAGNIE DE NAVIGATION
LES CLAUSES DU CONNAISSEMENT
div.p: Strosa Brothers devaient recevoir d Anvers 500 barils de ciment, chargés par la Sphinx Line dont MM. Lambert et Ralli sont les représentants à Alexandrie. 200 barils seulement ont été livrés. Les 300 barils restants étant introuvables, la Compagnie de Navigation proposait à ses clients de lui livrer en échange 300 barils d'une antre marque et d'une autre qualité supérieure qu'ils ont déposés aux Bonded Stores.
Refus de MM. Strosa qui, à défaut de la marchanadise, en réclament la valeur, ainsi que le remboursement des frais y afférant et des dommages intérêts.
L'affaire est venue devant le tribunal sommaire mixte d'Alexandrie le 11 courant.

L'avocat de la défense a fait valoir la clause du connaissement qui porte ''que ni le capitaine. ni l'armateur peuvent être responsables ni du poids, mesure, marques, etc. bien que spécifiés dans le connaissement, et que, en acceptant ce connaissement le propriétaire, le chargeur, ou tout autre agent du propriétaire accepte et agrée à toutes les clauses et conditions imprimées, écrites on estampilléss". Il a déclaré cette clause en tos points admissible et l'a appuyée de textes puisés dans la jurisprudence de toute l'Europe.

Le tribunal en a jugé autrement. Selon la jurisprudence mixte, a-t-il dit, les clauses telles que celle invoquée par la Compagnie défenderesse ne sont pas admissibles, si la faute provient de l'armateur. Or, c'est bien le cas en l'espèce, puisque la perte de 300 barils dûment livrés à Anvers et débarqués à Alexandrie constitue une preuve plus que suffisante de la négligence de la compaguie. De plus, le destinataire est parfaitement en droit de repousser l'offre d'échange et de récamer un juste dé dommageent du préjudice souffert. M.M. Stross recevront done le prix de leur marchandise, le montant des frais, plus une indemnité de 10% pour l'affaire manques.

div.head: BULETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourdhui à midi et demie.)
Le calme règue sur notre marché où les valeurs demeurent pour la plupart sans changement et sans transactions.
Quelques échanges seulement ont en lieu, comme précédemment, en Agricole, National Bank, Delta Light, Trust, Estates et Comptoir.
On offre l'Agricole à 9 11/16 et la National à 26 3/16.
La Ramleh Railway réactionne de 7 1/8 à 7 1/16, tandis que la Delta Light est ferme à 11 11/16 acheteurs.
La Delta Land clôture sans changement à 3 11/32 3/8, avec affaires clairsemées.
De 1 3/8 le Trust s'avance à 1 13/32, accentuant ainsi le mouvement de hausse qui se dessine depuis deux ou trois jours.
Par contre les Estates sont un peu plus fai blés à 1 13/16 vendeurs.
Lé Comptoir Financier demeure stationnaire aux cours respectifs de 6 19/32 l'ancienne et 6 7/16 la nouvelle.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
La Caire, 29 Août.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais est resté hier invarié à 87 7/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 3/4. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 26 3/8. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 3/4, ainsi que la Delta Light à 11 5/8. La Daira a perdu 1/8 à 16 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé en baissa de 3 francs à 751. La Banque d'Athènes est restée à 142.
Le nouvel emprunt russe 1906 a encore perdu 60 centimes, à Paris, à 79,60.
Ici, la séance de ce matin n'a pas précisément brillé par l'animation et l'activité. Marché calme, avec des transactions clairseméses e'des écarts peu importants.
La National Bank s'est raffermie à 26 3/16. L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a progressé à 222 et la Banque d'Abyssinie à 5 15/16-6.
L'action Crédit Foncier a été offerte à 754 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne s'est inscrite à 334.
La Nile Land a atteint 14 1/8 pour fioir à 13 15/16 14. Le Warden Estate a été coté 6 5/8-3/4. Ls. Gharbieh a été demandée à 3 13/16
L'action Immobile e a été bien tenue à 387*388 ; la part de fondateur a passé de 70 à 715. L'Agricole du Nil a rétrogradé à 263

L'actio Allotment a fléchi à 3 3/8-7/16 ; la part de fondateur s'est maintenue à 130. Les Héliopolis sout restés à 318 et et la part di fondateur à 8 5/8. Les Automobiles ont encore perdu 1/16 à 5 5 1/16.
Là part Bourse Khédiviale a été négociée à £155.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich se sont alourdis à 17 3/8-7/16. Les Egyptian ont conservé leur prix d'hier, soit 6 3/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates ont molli à 1 3/16 ; leur part de fondateur a, par coutre, avancé à 11 5/8-11/16. Les Sucreries ont été offerts à 23 francs et les Cotton Mills à 6 sh.
La nouvelle de l'arrivée prochaine de Nungovich bey, attendu lundi par le paquebot du Lloyd Autrichien, a dot né naissance à tonte une série du rumeurs sensationnelles.
On a ainsi fait courir à nonveau eu Bourse le bruit que les pourparlers pour la fusion de la George Nungovich Hotels Co. avec l'Egyptian Hotels Co. auraient été repris.
D'autre part, on affirme, contradictoirement, que Nungovich bey a l'intention "de transformer le Mena House en Casino d'hiver, à l'instar des meilleurs établissements de ce genre existant en Europe.

Ou ajoute. il est vrai, qu'il ne serait donné suite à ce projet que dans le cas seul où les négociations relatives à la fusion avec les Egyptian Hotels n'aboutiraient pas, car le Ghezireh Palace Hotel, sis sur les rives da Nil, serait l'endroit indiqué pour un Casino, à moins qu'on ne crée un lac artificiel et divers antres agréments onéreux dans le sable des Pyramides.
Toujours est il que qui vivra verra.

On fait courir la rumeur que l'Egyptian Constructions Ltd. projetterait l'émission et le placement de £500,000 d'obligations à l'effet d'entreprendre la construction de maisons économiques au Caire, avec faculté pour les locataires de devenir acquéreurs des immeubles moyennant des paiements échelonnés sur un certain nombre d'années.

Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine an 25 Août courant se sont élevées à L.E. 1,969 contre 1,647 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 322. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 se chiff ent par L.E. 51,872 contre 43,917 en 1905, soit en plus-value de L.E. 7,905 pour l'exercice courant.
Les recettes de l'Alexandria Ramleh Railway Co. pour la semaine au 25 Août ont été de L.E. 1,502 contre 1,278 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 224,
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre 905 se sont élevées à L. E 55,846 contre 14,813 pour l'exercise précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 11,034.

div.head: DECES
div.p: Nous avons le regret d'annoncer la mort de M. GIUSEPPINO GRASSO, survenne hier à 4 heures de l'après-midi, à la suite d'une pneumonie. Ce jeune homme, agé de 23 ans seulement, l'espoir de sa famille, était en train de se créer une brillante position.
Les amis et connaissances du défunt sont priés d'assister à la cérémonie mortuaire qui aura lieu ce soir à 4 h. 3/4 à Bulkeley, maison Pinto.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
div.p: The demand for Egyptians continues very limited, and the amount of business small, prices being in buyers' favour, but without change in quotations. In Futures a fair business has been doe, and the latest values are, delivery : —
American Futures. The market this week has been active, but except for an occasional rally the tone has been weak, and prices have again fallen heavily.

To-day's closing values are 23 @ 25 points below those of last Thursday. The chief reasons of the decline are the continuance of generally favourable crop conditions, and a very widespread Bear sentiment which is of course accentuated every now and again by heavy Bear manipulation in all the markets. No doubt the present condition of the crop is very favourable, but the crop is not yet made and it is possible that the extremely bearish feeling is, to some extent, exaggerating the prospects of the yield. Prices may, of course, decline further : on the other hand it would take very little to change the general sentiment of the markets, and the short interest most now be very extensive.
The following are the latest quotations :—
August 5.04 ½ d Nov/Dec. 4.91 Mar./Apl. 4.96 ½

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier de "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parais chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir ètre expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der nières statistiques jusqu'à la veil e de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la dlace et les copies des dépêchas officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
INSURRECTION THWARTED.
LABOUR APPEAL TO ARMY.

div.p: It is stated that an insurrection had been planned to take place in October, and vast quantities of arms and explosives were purchased for the occasion, but that it has been thwarted owing to the arrest of a number of the conspirators.
The Tsar and the Grand Duke Nicholas were amongst the bearers of General Minn's coffin at his funeral yesterday. (Reuter)
It is officially declared that the Government will not adopt any weaker policy in dealing with revolutionists, however horrible their threats may be.

A manifesto issued by the ex-Labour Members of the Duma to the army says that the soldiers are sworn to loyalty not only to the Tsar, but to the Fatherland as well, which the Tsar has deceived. It urges the army to fulfil its oath to the fatherland and to fight for the authority of the people.
Bomb outrages and bomb discoveries are reported throughout Russia.
Despatches from the Baltic provinces, Georgia, and others parts of the Caucasus, show that the Territorists have established their own government.
The Russian township of Mordovo has been burned; 2,000 people are homeless. (Reuter)

div.head:
NATAL AND CAPE COLONY.
RELATIONS STRAINED.

div.p: Relations between Natal and Cape Colony are strained owing to the Cape's adjustment of railway rates detrimental to Natal. There is a movement on foot here in favour of a complete union with the Transvaal whereby Natal would secure the Transvaal's trade and the Transvaal would secure a harbour of her own. The tendency in the ease of both colonies is to isolate the Cape. (Reuter)

div.head:
DEFYING THE VATICAN.
TRIUMPH FOR SPANISH LIBERALISM.

div.p: In defiance of the opposition shown by the Vatican, King Alfonso has signed a decree abolishing the previous right of the Church to interfere in civil marriages. This is regarded as a triumph for Liberalism in Spain. (Reuter)

A sensation has been caused throughout America by the failure of the Real Estate Trust Company, one of the strongest financial institutions in Philadelphia. £1,400,000 is involved. Its president, Mr. Hippie, one of the most prominent Presbyterian Churchmen, has committed suicide. (Reuter)
The son of the German Crown Prince has been christened here to-day. (Reuter)
The baptism of the Kronprirz'a son takes place today. He will be called William Frederick Francis Joseph. (Havas)
Mr. Haldane has arrived here. (Reuter)
The Earl of Lovelace is dead. (Reuter)
It has been confirmed that the Wellmann expedition has been abandoned. (Reuter)
The Marquis of San Giuliano has been appointed Ambassador at London. (Reuter)

Cricket.—Kent beat Middlesex by 7 wickets. Srrey beat Derbyshire by 10 wickets. Yorkshire beat Somerset by 389 runs. The matches between Worcester hire v. Gloucestershire and Sussex v. Essex were drawn.

The Persian Ambassador has vigorously protested against the Turkish occupation of the district of Margovar, contrary to the promise of a friendly settlement of the frontier. The Porte denies the alleged encroachments. (Reuter)
The Turkish troops on the Persian frontier have occupied the district of Margovar. The Persian Ambassador has protested, but the Porte denies any encroachment. (Havas)

div.head: ANTI-TYPHOID CAMPAIGN
LORD KITCHENER'S SUGGESTIONS.
div.p: Presiding recently at Simla over the first meeting of the Committee on Enteric Fever, Lord Kitchener, in his address, said:—I have thought it necessary to form this standing committee to advise us in our efforts to reduce enteric fever among the troops in this country, and to co-ordinate the work of the whole medical profession, civil and military, in this direction. The ravages of cholera were worse in the Army in India in days gone by, but they are now happily a reminiscence of the past, and, if we consider enteric fever as a not less dangerous disease, and are equally energetic in stamping it out, I have great hopes that we shall succeed in bringing this scourge in turn eventually under control. We know that the time when young soldiers are most subject to enteric is on their first arrival in this country, and at certain seasons of the year the prevalence of the disease may be anticipated.

You are aware that we have been engaged for some time on experiments in anti-typhoid inoculation in India, and great advances have been made on the system prevailing at the time of the South African war. By anti typhoid inoculatio we can assist the soldier's tissues to resist the disease by providing fluids in the blood which re-act and have disastrous effects on a bacterial invasion by typhoid germs. Recent experience proves that we can obtain fruitful results by this means, but, though we have in inoculation a possible solution, this method of treatment is still comparatively in its infancy, and, though we have sufficient data to justify us in introducing the system generally, I look forward to great improvement in its operation. Though the devoted professional experts in India and at home, by careful investigation and practical experience, will do away with some of the drawbacks now attending the process, I think the medical profession are not always folly alive to the thoughtlessness of the soldier as regards taking care of himself. They provide a safeguard against dangerous disease, but it causes considerable discomfort, and yet they are surprised that it is not more willingly adopted.

If we want to make inoculation popular generally,I think our efforts should be directed to making its application less painful and unpleasant, even at the expense of some reduction in the period of immunity. The line of thought and inquiry I should like to set before you is whether this cannot be accomplished by using a more diluted serum, or distributing the dose over three or more injections, instead of two, as the practice now is, or reducing the amount of serum injected. I only suggest these views as a layman for your consideration as experts. Since the South African war the dose has been reduced considerably with good results, Cannot you go a step further in the same direction ? Are you convinoed that you have reached the minimum of safety ? Are you not aiming at too long a period of immunity ? If all discomfort could be avoided in the process of inoculation an immune period of six months might be sufficient, instead of the two years you now aspire to. Then we might look for universal inoculation of all arrivals in this country.

div.head: PERFIDIOUS LOVER.
div.p: SAD EXPERIENCE OF A RICH WIDOW.
A rich Parisian widow has just had a painful experience of man's perfidy.

She met the man at a watering-place. He paid her flattering attentions, and they strolled together in the woods. Though forty, her heart was at still youthful, and as they sat in the shade, says the "Telegraph," the lover stole a kiss. A gendarme came from behind a tree, and said that he most summon them for improper behaviour. The lover suggested bribery and corruption to avoid scandal.

Unluckily he had left his money at home, so the widow gave the gendarme £80 and her gold watch. A plain clothes man, who was with the gendarme, demanded his baksheesh. In default of cash he accepted a note of hand for £2,000.

The widow went home to Paris alone with strange suspicions arising. She determined to repudiate the note of hand. When the plain clothes man wrote threatening exposure if she did not meet him at the St. Lazare terminus and pay the £2,000 she kept the appointment, accompanied by two detectives. The plain clothes man was arrested, and so was the perfidious lover, who was found at the other's lodgings.
The two will shortly be tried. The "gendarme" is still at large.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The Bank position shows an improvement and the proportion of reserve has arisen showing nearly £27,000,000 of gold, 50.36 of the liabilities against 46.7 same time last year. In the outside market there is no change, rates for loans varying from 2 ¼ to 3 per cent, and discounts 3 5/16 to 3/8. There seems no reason to look for any change in the easy position of money here for another month at least, and not then unless the United States require our assistance to provide part of the £15,000,000 needed for moving their large crops. As to the probability of this opinions differ, but the best informed do not anticipate any withdrawal sufficient to create monetary tension. Last year New York took £4,000,000 from this side and it is not probable, in view of the strong gold position of the United States Treasury, that more than this will be taken, if as much.

Reviewing the position as a whole we have Berlin with gold sufficient to take care of its own wants, but with no surplus in view of its present active trade. The Bank of France in its usual commanding position can part with some of its large supplies, if need be, and the Bank of England is in a position to part with a moderate amount Russia and Japan may call for some of their large deposits, the former having taken the £500,000 sent to Germany for an "unknown destination," and are probably about to take more shortly. The United States may have large requirements in the near future but are in a position to provide for themselves in case of any money pressure, and finally there is the usual demand from Egypt, which may amount to £4,000,000 or even more. There is nothing in this situation to create uneasiness. Good supplies of gold are arriving from the mines, but what makes any serious situation in the autumn very unlikely is that it is not to the interest of any market to check the exceptional business now existing in all the countries involved (excepting Russia).
A moderate amount of buying in the silver market has raised the price of spot to 80 7/8 d. but there has been no alteration for two months' shipment which remains 30 ¾ d. per ounce.

It would seem at last the stock markets have taken a turn for the better, and a decided improvement has been noted generally during the past week. Consols seem to have been rather a weak spot, but after declining to 87 ½ for the account, have recovered somewhat and close to-night at 87 3/4. On receipt of the news of the earthquake at Valparaiso, it was feared that the Insurance Companies would have to realise some of their investments but this has not actually been the case. Apart from the fact that their liabilities are not nearly so large as was the case in San Francisco, the general manager of the Atlas Assurance Company has been authorized by all the British Insurance Companies who have business in Chili to repudiate the statement that the companies have any intention to go beyond their strict legal contracts, which clearly exempt them from all liability from loss or damage by fires consequent upon earthquake. Chilian issues have been marked down a few points generally, but there has been no tendency to panic. Reports from most of the British Companies having interests in Chili are favourable, and business is being resumed generally. It is also reported that no damage has been done to the nitrate deposits. A telegram from Lima states that the damage done by the earthquake is immense, and that the Government will ask the Chilian Congress to appropriate £20,000,000 for the rebuilding of the city.
In the Railway market the large increases in the traffic returns of the principal railway companies have failed to influence these stocks and prices have eased off generally.
Profit taking in nearly all departments has called a halt on the upward tendency which was displayed earlier in the week, and there seems to be an inclination to mark time.

With the announcement of a 5 per cent dividend for the half year on Union Pacifics (making 10 per cent for the year), and 2 ½ per cent. on Southern Pacifics, Yankee rails put on a spurt, prices rising by leaps and bounds, but owing to dear money prices have shown some irregularity. Steels are strong on rumours that the corporation has secured valuable ore lands, also on autumn dividend prospects. There has not been much done in Canadian Rails, which have, however, moved in sympathy with Yankees.

The Egyptian Market has once more relapsed into a state of stagnation, and prices are slightly easier on balance. Bank of Egypt recovered ½ to 37*28. National Bank of Egypt after being buyers at 26 1/8, close very doubtful at 25 13/16, and Agricultural Bank of Egypt are only 9 ¾ . Daira Sanieh Ordinary have changed hands at 16 ¾ and are still about this price, and the deferred are nominally 95*9. Land Bank of Egypt have been in request from Paris and close a shade better at 8 ¾ -9, bat Bank of Abyssinia are still a very bad market at about 1 discount. Delta Land and Investment are 3 ½ with nothing doing, and Delta Light Ry. Pref. are ll ½ -12. Khedivial Mail are still enquired for at 34/6, but there are no sellers at this price, and the Preference are quoted 4 ½ - ¾ . Egyptian Estates are steady at 1 15/16 also Union Foncière @ 6 1/8 and Daira Sugar at 5 1/8. Corporation of Western Egypt at ¼ premium sellers. There is absolutely no market in Salt & Soda or Egyptian Markets, and the prices are unchanged at 1 1/16 and l ¼ respectively. Bank of Roumania are ¼ better at 10 ¼.
Egyptian Mining shares have declined. United Africans have receded 1 1/2. Nile Valleys 6d. to 6s. aid "Mummies" 3d.

The Kaffir market has shown a somewhat erratic tendency during the last day or two. Profit taking has helped to put prices down, and bear operations have helped still further in the depression. Rhodesians have participated in the decline, and general marking down of values has ensued. Premier shares have receded to 15 1/8, bat De Beers and Montrose recovered slightly, the former being in demand on Paris accouny. Rand Mines are sellers at 6 9/16. Gold Fields have relapsed to 4 ½ which leaves them down 5/32 on the day. In the Copper section prices have shown a rallying tendency, Anacondas being bid up to 14 1/4, but closing at 14 1/8. Rios have also come up for a share of support.

A good deal of interest has lately been taken in this market, particularly in Iron and Steel shares, and business has been on a very fair scale. Ebbw Vale advanced ¼ to 8 ½ . Cammell Laird new debentures improved to 1 premium. Cotton and Textile shares are without feature, prices remaining unaltered.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
KHEDIVAL YACHT CLUB
div.p: REGATTA.
The following is the result of yesterday's regatta :

The wind was very fresh from the N. W. A very exciting finish was witnessed in Class I., when the first four boats crossed the finishing line within 35 seconds. The Shamrock won in Class II. The Ananké unfortunately carried away one of her backstays when outside, which so hindered her that she gave up the race. She appears to be a very lightly built boat and not suited for a heavy sea.
